metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Static methods can be called directly - without creating an instance of the class first.
content.html: Static methods can be called directly - without creating an instance of the class first.

content.text: Static methods are declared with the static keyword:
content.html: Static methods are declared with the static keyword:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php
    class ClassName {  public static function staticMethod() {    
    echo "Hello World!";  }}?>

content.code:
<?php
class ClassName {  public static function staticMethod() {
echo "Hello World!";  }}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php
 class ClassName {  public static function staticMethod() {    
 echo "Hello World!";  }}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class ClassName {
  public static function staticMethod() {
    echo "Hello World!";
  }
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php
    class ClassName {  public static function staticMethod() {    
    echo "Hello World!";  }}?>

content.text: To access a static method use the class name, double colon (::), and the method name:
content.html: To access a static method use the class name, double colon (::), and the method name:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass 
    greeting {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
    // Call static method
    greeting::welcome();?>

content.code:
<?phpclass 
greeting {  public static function
welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
// Call static method
greeting::welcome();?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass 
    greeting {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
 // Call static method
    greeting::welcome();?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class greeting {
  public static function welcome() {
    echo "Hello World!";
  }
}

// Call static method
 greeting::welcome();
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass 
    greeting {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
    // Call static method
    greeting::welcome();?>

content.text: Here, we declare a static method: welcome(). Then, we call the static method by using the class name, double colon (::), and the method name (without creating an instance of the class first).
content.html: Here, we declare a static method: welcome(). Then, we call the static method by using the class name, double colon (::), and the method name (without creating an instance of the class first).

content.text: A class can have both static and non-static methods. A static method can be accessed from a method in the same class using the self keyword and double colon (::):
content.html: A class can have both static and non-static methods. A static method can be accessed from a method in the same class using the self keyword and double colon (::):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass greeting {  public static function welcome() {    
    echo "Hello World!";  }  public function __construct() 
    {    self::welcome();  }}new 
    greeting();?>

content.code:
<?phpclass greeting {  public static function welcome() {    
echo "Hello World!";  }  public function __construct()
{    self::welcome();  }}new
greeting();?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass greeting {  public static function welcome() {    
 echo "Hello World!";  }  public function __construct() 
    {    self::welcome();  }}new 
    greeting();?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class greeting {
  public static function welcome() {
    echo "Hello World!";
  }

  public function __construct() {
    self::welcome();
  }
}

new greeting();
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass greeting {  public static function welcome() {    
    echo "Hello World!";  }  public function __construct() 
    {    self::welcome();  }}new 
    greeting();?>

content.text: Static methods can also be called from methods in other classes. To do this, the static method should be public :
content.html: Static methods can also be called from methods in other classes. To do this, the static method should be public:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass 
    A {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
    class 
    B {  public function 
    message() {   
    A::welcome();  }}$obj = new B();echo $obj -> 
    message(); ?>

content.code:
<?phpclass 
A {  public static function
welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
class
B {  public function
message() {
A::welcome();  }}$obj = new B();echo $obj ->
message(); ?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass 
    A {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
 class 
    B {  public function 
    message() {   
    A::welcome();  }}$obj = new B();echo $obj -> 
    message(); ?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class A {
  public static function welcome() {
    echo "Hello World!";
  }
}

class B {
  public function message() {
    A::welcome();
  }
}

$obj = new B();
echo $obj -> message();
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass 
    A {  public static function 
    welcome() {    echo "Hello World!";  }}
    class 
    B {  public function 
    message() {   
    A::welcome();  }}$obj = new B();echo $obj -> 
    message(); ?>

content.text: To call a static method from a child class, use the parent keyword inside the child class. Here, the static method can be public or protected .
content.html: To call a static method from a child class, use the parent keyword inside the child class. Here, the static method can be public or protected.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass domain {  protected static function 
    getWebsiteName() {    return "W3Schools.com";  }
    }class domainW3 extends domain {  public $websiteName;  
    public function __construct() {    $this->websiteName = 
    parent::getWebsiteName();  } }$domainW3 = new domainW3;
    echo $domainW3 -> websiteName;?>

content.code:
<?phpclass domain {  protected static function 
getWebsiteName() {    return "W3Schools.com";  }
}class domainW3 extends domain {  public $websiteName;
public function __construct() {    $this->websiteName =
parent::getWebsiteName();  } }$domainW3 = new domainW3;
echo $domainW3 -> websiteName;?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass domain {  protected static function 
    getWebsiteName() {    return "W3Schools.com";  }
    }class domainW3 extends domain {  public $websiteName;  
 public function __construct() {    $this->websiteName = 
    parent::getWebsiteName();  } }$domainW3 = new domainW3;
 echo $domainW3 -> websiteName;?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class domain {
  protected static function getWebsiteName() {
    return "W3Schools.com";
  }
}

class domainW3 extends domain {
  public $websiteName;
  public function __construct() {
    $this->websiteName = parent::getWebsiteName();
  }
}

$domainW3 = new domainW3;
echo $domainW3 -> websiteName;
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass domain {  protected static function 
    getWebsiteName() {    return "W3Schools.com";  }
    }class domainW3 extends domain {  public $websiteName;  
    public function __construct() {    $this->websiteName = 
    parent::getWebsiteName();  } }$domainW3 = new domainW3;
    echo $domainW3 -> websiteName;?>
